kpi.title: Key Performance Indicators
kpi.name: KPI Name
kpi.efficiencyDescription: Track production output against targets and identify improvement areas
kpi.otdDescription: Track delivery performance and identify delays to improve customer satisfaction
kpi.wipAgingDescription: Monitor work-in-progress inventory age to optimize production flow
kpi.availabilityDescription: Monitor equipment uptime and identify downtime patterns for improvement
kpi.performanceDescription: Monitor production speed and throughput efficiency
kpi.qualityDescription: Comprehensive quality analysis: PPM, DPMO, FPY, RTY
kpi.oeeDescription: Comprehensive productivity metric combining Availability, Performance, and Quality
kpi.absenteeismDescription: Track employee attendance patterns and absence rates
kpi.reworkRateTooltipMeaning: Percentage of units that required in-line corrections or quick fixes. Rework is typically handled by the same operator without significant additional resources.
kpi.repairRateTooltipMeaning: Percentage of units requiring significant resources or external repair. Repair involves dedicated repair stations, specialized personnel, or external services.
kpi.scrapRateTooltipMeaning: Percentage of units that could not be salvaged and were discarded. These units failed quality and could not be successfully reworked or repaired.
kpi.recoveryRateTooltipMeaning: Percentage of failed units that were successfully recovered through rework or repair (vs scrapped). Higher is better - indicates ability to save defective units.
kpi.ariaOpenQrScanner: Open QR code scanner for quick data entry
kpi.oeeFormula: OEE = Availability x Performance x Quality

tooltips.fpyFormula: FPY = (Units Passed First Time / Total Units Inspected) x 100
tooltips.fpyMeaning: Percentage of units that pass quality inspection on the first attempt without any rework or repair needed.
tooltips.rtyFormula: RTY = FPY1 x FPY2 x FPY3 x ... x FPYn
tooltips.rtyMeaning: Probability that a unit passes through ALL inspection stages (Incoming, In-Process, Final) without requiring any rework at any stage.
tooltips.finalYieldFormula: Final Yield = (Total Inspected - Scrapped) / Total Inspected x 100
tooltips.finalYieldMeaning: Percentage of units that ultimately passed quality (either first time or after successful rework). Only scrapped units are excluded.
tooltips.totalInspectedMeaning: Total number of units that went through quality inspection during the selected period.
tooltips.firstPassGoodMeaning: Number of units that passed quality inspection on the first attempt without requiring any rework.
tooltips.totalScrappedMeaning: Number of units that could not be salvaged and were discarded. These units failed quality and could not be reworked successfully.
tooltips.efficiencyMeaning: Measures how well resources are utilized to produce output. Target is 85%. Higher efficiency indicates better resource utilization.
tooltips.actualOutputMeaning: Total number of units actually produced within the selected period. This is the numerator for efficiency calculation.
tooltips.expectedOutputMeaning: Target number of units based on standard production rates and available time. This is the benchmark for measuring efficiency.
tooltips.gapMeaning: Difference between actual and expected output. Positive (green) means exceeding target; negative (red) means below target.
tooltips.actualRateFormula: Actual Rate = Total Units / Production Hours
tooltips.actualRateMeaning: Current production speed in units per hour. Compare against standard rate to identify performance gaps.
tooltips.standardRateMeaning: Target production speed based on equipment design capacity and optimal conditions. This is the benchmark for performance measurement.
tooltips.totalUnitsMeaning: Total number of units produced within the selected period. This is the raw output measure before quality adjustments.
tooltips.productionHoursMeaning: Total hours spent in active production (excluding downtime). Used to calculate actual production rate and performance efficiency.
tooltips.totalEmployeesMeaning: Total number of employees scheduled to work within the selected period. This is the workforce baseline for calculating absenteeism metrics.
tooltips.totalAbsencesMeaning: Total number of absence instances recorded. Each day an employee is absent counts as one absence, regardless of partial or full day.
tooltips.scheduledHoursFormula: Scheduled Hours = Sum(Employee Hours x Working Days)
tooltips.scheduledHoursMeaning: Total hours employees were scheduled to work. This is the denominator for calculating absenteeism rate percentage.
tooltips.absentHoursMeaning: Total hours lost due to employee absences. Used to calculate the absenteeism rate and estimate productivity impact.
tooltips.uptimeMeaning: Total hours equipment was operational and available for production. Higher uptime directly correlates with increased production capacity.
tooltips.downtimeMeaning: Total hours equipment was unavailable due to breakdowns, maintenance, changeovers, or other stoppages. Target is to minimize this value.
tooltips.totalTimeMeaning: Total scheduled production hours within the selected period. This represents the maximum potential operating time.
tooltips.mtbfFormula: MTBF = Total Uptime / Number of Failures
tooltips.mtbfMeaning: Mean Time Between Failures - average operating time between equipment breakdowns. Higher MTBF indicates more reliable equipment.
tooltips.availabilityMeaning: Percentage of scheduled time equipment is available for production. Accounts for breakdowns, changeovers, and unplanned stops. Target: 90%+
tooltips.performanceMeaning: Measures production speed relative to design capacity. Accounts for slow cycles, minor stops, and reduced speed. Target: 95%+
tooltips.qualityMeaning: First Pass Yield - percentage of units passing inspection without rework. Accounts for defects, scrap, and rework. Target: 99%+
tooltips.totalDeliveriesMeaning: Total number of deliveries scheduled or completed within the selected date range. This is the base for OTD percentage calculation.
tooltips.onTimeMeaning: Number of deliveries completed on or before the promised delivery date. Higher numbers indicate better planning and execution.
tooltips.lateFormula: Late = Total Deliveries - On Time Deliveries
tooltips.lateMeaning: Number of deliveries that missed the promised date. Analyze root causes to improve future performance.
tooltips.otdRateMeaning: Percentage of orders delivered by the promised date. Target is 95%. Critical for customer satisfaction and contract compliance.
tooltips.totalWipMeaning: Total number of units currently in work-in-process status. These are items that have started production but are not yet complete.
tooltips.averageAgeFormula: Avg Age = Sum of All WIP Ages / Total WIP Items
tooltips.averageAgeMeaning: Average number of days items have been in WIP status. Lower values indicate faster throughput and more efficient production flow.
tooltips.oldestItemMeaning: Age of the oldest item currently in WIP. High values may indicate production bottlenecks, quality holds, or material shortages requiring immediate attention.
tooltips.criticalItemsMeaning: Number of WIP items aged over 14 days. These require urgent attention as they impact delivery schedules and tie up working capital.

inferenceIndicator.hintText: This value includes estimated data. For full accuracy, enter actual values in the data entry forms.

admin.partOpportunitiesDescription: Configure defect opportunities per part for accurate DPMO calculation
admin.partOpportunitiesInfo: DPMO calculation uses opportunities per unit to measure defects per million opportunities. Different parts have different complexity levels affecting the number of potential defect opportunities.
admin.deletePartOpportunityConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete opportunities for part {part}?
admin.opportunitiesHint: Number of potential defect locations per unit (e.g., 10 for simple, 50+ for complex)

partGuide.title: Part Opportunities Guide
partGuide.whatAreDescription: Part Opportunities represent the number of potential defect points per unit of a product. This is a critical input for calculating DPMO (Defects Per Million Opportunities), a key Six Sigma quality metric.
partGuide.qualityMeasurementDesc: Enable accurate DPMO calculation for Six Sigma analysis
partGuide.fairComparisonDesc: Compare quality across products with different complexity levels
partGuide.accuracyWarning: Accurate opportunity counts are essential for meaningful DPMO calculations. Underestimating opportunities inflates DPMO, while overestimating deflates it.
partGuide.fieldComplexityDesc: Simple, Standard, Complex, or Very Complex
partGuide.step3Review: Review the data and click Save
partGuide.step3Available: The part will now be available for quality calculations
partGuide.csvFormatHint: Use CSV upload to import multiple parts at once. Click "Download Template" to get the correct format.
partGuide.determiningCountDesc: Count all potential defect points in a product. Consider:
partGuide.tipText: Work with your quality team to establish consistent opportunity counting methods across all products. Document your counting methodology for consistency.

poolGuide.whatIsDescription: The Floating Pool is a shared workforce that can be temporarily assigned to different clients based on demand. This helps optimize staffing levels across your organization.
poolGuide.poolEmployeesDesc: Workers designated as flexible resources who can work across multiple clients
poolGuide.availableDesc: Workers currently not assigned to any client, ready to be deployed
poolGuide.assignedDesc: Workers currently working for a specific client
poolGuide.utilizationDesc: Percentage of pool employees currently assigned (higher = more efficient use)
poolGuide.totalDesc: Total workers in the floating pool
poolGuide.assignStep1a: Find an available employee in the table (green "Available" badge)
poolGuide.assignStep2a: Select the target client from the dropdown
poolGuide.assignStep2b: Optionally set availability dates (start and end)
poolGuide.assignStep3c: The employee status will change to "Assigned"
poolGuide.unassignWarning: Unassigning returns the employee to the available pool, making them ready for new assignments.
poolGuide.unassignStep1: Find the assigned employee in the table
poolGuide.unassignStep3: The employee will immediately become available
poolGuide.filterClientDesc: Show only employees assigned to a specific client
poolGuide.rushSituation: Client needs additional workers to meet a tight deadline
poolGuide.rushStep1: Check the "Available" count in the summary cards
poolGuide.rushStep2: Filter by Status -> "Available" to see all free workers
poolGuide.rushStep3: Assign multiple workers to the client needing help
poolGuide.rushStep4: Set the "Available To" date to when the rush period ends
poolGuide.rushStep5: Monitor the Simulation Insights for staffing recommendations
poolGuide.absentStep1: Check the absenteeism alert in the Alerts dashboard
poolGuide.absentStep3: Check available pool workers with relevant skills
poolGuide.absentStep4: Assign workers for the day or shift needed
poolGuide.balanceSituation: One client is over-staffed while another needs help
poolGuide.balanceStep1: Filter by Client -> Select the over-staffed client
poolGuide.balanceStep2: Identify workers who can be reassigned
poolGuide.balanceStep3: Unassign them from the current client
poolGuide.balanceStep4: Assign them to the client needing additional staff
poolGuide.balanceStep5: Review the Simulation Insights for optimal distribution
poolGuide.bp1: Keep at least 10-15% of pool workers available for emergencies
poolGuide.bp2: Set end dates for temporary assignments to auto-track availability
poolGuide.bp3: Review Simulation Insights regularly for optimization opportunities
poolGuide.bp4: Add notes to assignments for context and tracking
poolGuide.bpAvoid: Avoid assigning all pool workers - maintain flexibility buffer
poolGuide.insightsDesc: uses production simulation data to provide staffing recommendations and scenario analysis.
poolGuide.scenariosDesc: The system simulates different staffing levels and shows predicted outcomes:
poolGuide.scenarioMinimumDesc: Fewest workers that meet basic production needs
poolGuide.scenarioOptimalDesc: Best balance of efficiency and output
poolGuide.highPriorityDesc: Urgent actions that may impact production
poolGuide.tipText: Click "Refresh" in the Simulation Insights panel to get updated recommendations based on current data.

workflowConfig.transitionHint: Configure which statuses can transition to each target status.
workflowConfig.templateWarning: This will replace the current workflow configuration. Existing work orders will not be affected.

closureHints.atCompletion: Orders close immediately when production completes (skip shipping)

simulationV2.title: Production Line Simulation v2.0
simulationV2.subtitle: Discrete-event simulation for multi-product production lines with bottleneck analysis and rebalancing suggestions

guide.title: Production Line Simulation v2.0 Guide
guide.step1: Define your production operations using the grid. Paste from Excel or add manually.
guide.step2: Configure shifts, work days, and overtime settings.
guide.step3: Set daily/weekly demand per product or use mix percentages.
guide.step4: Click "Run Simulation" to execute the discrete-event simulation.
guide.fieldOperatorsDesc: Number of operators at this station
guide.tipPasteExcel: Copy/paste data directly from Excel. The grid auto-detects columns.
guide.fpdDesc: First Pass Defect adds rework time
guide.rebalancingExplanation: The rebalancing suggestions identify stations that could donate operators to bottleneck stations.

resetDialog.clearAllSubtitle: Remove all data and start with empty configuration
resetDialog.loadSampleSubtitle: Reset with T-Shirt manufacturing example for learning

welcome.title: Welcome!
welcome.message: Sample T-Shirt manufacturing data has been loaded to help you get started.

alerts.resolvePlaceholder: Describe how the issue was resolved...

guide.title: How to Use Intelligent Alerts
guide.welcomeDescription: This system proactively monitors your KPIs and notifies you when thresholds are exceeded or patterns indicate potential issues.
guide.step1: View Active Alerts - The dashboard shows all current alerts organized by severity
guide.step2: Filter Alerts - Use the dropdown filters to focus on specific categories or severities
guide.step3: Check Now - Click "Check Now" to trigger an immediate scan of all KPIs
guide.step4: Take Action - Acknowledge, resolve, or dismiss alerts as you address issues
guide.urgentDesc: Immediate action required - Critical business impact
guide.otdDesc: Monitors work orders at risk of missing delivery dates. Triggers when:
guide.otdTrigger2: Work order is approaching due date with insufficient progress
guide.qualityDesc: Tracks quality metrics including FPY, RTY, PPM, and DPMO. Triggers when:
guide.qualityTrigger1: First Pass Yield drops below threshold
guide.efficiencyDesc: Monitors production efficiency and performance. Triggers when:
guide.capacityDesc: Tracks staffing and capacity utilization. Triggers when:
guide.capacityTrigger1: Available workforce insufficient for planned production
guide.capacityTrigger2: Floating pool utilization is critically high
guide.attendanceDesc: Monitors absenteeism patterns using Bradford Factor. Triggers when:
guide.attendanceTrigger2: Team absenteeism rate is unusually high
guide.holdsDesc: Tracks WIP aging and hold duration. Triggers when:
guide.holdsTrigger1: Items on hold exceed maximum age threshold
guide.bp1: Acknowledge promptly - Let your team know you're handling the issue
guide.bp2: Add resolution notes - Document what was done for future reference
guide.bp3: Review patterns - Look for recurring alerts to address root causes
guide.bp4: Configure thresholds - Adjust alert thresholds in Admin Settings
guide.bp5: Don't dismiss without action - Only dismiss if alert is no longer relevant
guide.scenario1Alert: Work Order WO-2024-001 at risk - Only 60% complete with 2 days remaining
guide.scenario1Step3: Consider adding floating pool workers or overtime
guide.scenario1Step5: Resolve with notes explaining actions taken
guide.scenario2Step1: Review recent quality entries for patterns
guide.scenario2Step2: Check defect types - is there a common cause?
guide.scenario2Step3: Inspect equipment or materials if needed

filterManager.title: Manage Saved Filters
filterManager.noFiltersMatchSearch: No filters match your search criteria.
filterManager.noFiltersSaved: You haven't saved any filters yet.
filterManager.deleteConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete {name}?
filterManager.clearHistoryConfirm: Are you sure you want to clear your filter history?
filterManager.clearHistoryDetail: This will remove {count} recent filter(s) from your history. Saved filters will not be affected.

saveFilterDialog.title: Save Filter
saveFilterDialog.setAsDefaultHint: This filter will be automatically applied when you visit this section
saveFilterDialog.noFiltersConfigured: No specific filters configured (shows all data)
saveFilterDialog.filterNameMin: Name must be at least 2 characters
saveFilterDialog.filterNameMax: Name must be less than 100 characters
saveFilterDialog.saveFailed: Failed to save filter. Please try again.
